results.title: Child draw nearer
results.creator_credit: Martin Shuttleworth, Annie Mygind and Bristol Films
results.brief_description: This film shows the advances made at a special school for teaching autistic children and how they began to respond to patience and to use language in a normal way. Commentary by Norman Tyrrell and Val Bryan.

results.title: Child care: the management challenge for the 1990's
results.creator_credit: Mark Gould, Susan Lambert and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Twenty percent of all women workers have children under five and in 56% of families with dependent children, both parents work. Inadequate childcare facilities for these working parents can result in high absenteeism, low productivity and a high turnover rate. More and more companies are seeing the advantages to providing a carefully planned work-based childcare centre which ultimately benefits not just the employees, but the employer and the children. This video provides several examples of Sydney-based companies who have taken the initiative, including the Vacation Program run jointly by the NAB, ANZ, NML and CML, the Messengers Cottage Creche for the Esso/Lend Lease employees and the Flemington Market’s proposed childcare centre. The consensus appears to be a higher retention of skilled workers, particularly women, and an overall improvement in productivity.

results.title: Child care means business
results.creator_credit: Louise Leitch, Elena Guest and Commonwealth Department of Human Services and Health
results.brief_description: A panel of employers debate employer sponsored child care, examining economic arguments together with philosophical and practical issues. Andrew Olle hosts a panel including small, medium and big business along with leading work and family strategists.

results.title: Child abuse: the people next door
results.creator_credit: Helen Garvey, Dan Bessie and Shire Films
results.brief_description: This film helps parents recognise the potential for child abuse within themselves and others, the kinds of situations that can make that potential a reality, and how and where to find help.

results.title: Child's play
results.creator_credit: Tom Holland, David Kirschner and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description: All Andy Barclay wants for his birthday is a Good Guy doll, regrettably his mother can’t afford one. Upset at being unable to deliver her son’s greatest wish, Karen goes to work only to discover a man selling Good Guy dolls in the alley behind the department store. She approaches the man, and for $30 the Good Guy doll is hers and she takes it home to Andy. However this is no ordinary doll. Following a police chase, serial killer Charles Lee Ray aka the Langshore Strangler, is shot and takes refuge in a doll factory. Before dying he uses voodoo to transfer his soul into a doll, the exact doll Karen buys for Andy. When Andy unwraps his new toy, ‘Chuckie’ continues to kill, his first victim, Andy’s Aunt Maggie. Andy tells the police ‘Chuckie did it’, but no one believes him and he is taken away to a psychiatric institution for children. When the murders continue, Karen discovers that Chuckie is battery-operated, and she forgot to insert his batteries. Detective Norris meets Chuckie and together they try to stop the doll’s killing spree. From an explosive start to an even more explosive ending, Child’s Play has become a cult film, spawning many sequels. Cast includes Catherine Hicks, Chris Sarandon, Alex Vincent and Brad Dourif as Chuckie.

results.title: Chicken run [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Peter Lord, Nick Park, David Sproxton, Pathe Image Production, Aardman Chicken Run Ltd and NBCUniversal
results.brief_description: Relying heavily on one of the most famous escape movies of all time - “The Great escape” (1963) - Aardman animations first feature length film has plenty to offer adults and children alike. Set on Tweedy’s poultry farm in the 1950’s, most of the inhabitants grumble about their lodgings but are paralysed by apathy, everyone that is except for Ginger, a feisty chicken who has come up with ingenious but ultimately unsuccessful escape plans. Their sheltered world is altered drastically when their is a new addition to their midst - Rocky, the flying rooster. Ginger, believing Rocky to be their salvation due to his capacity to fly (despite his gender), manages to convince him to whip the chickens into shape for a communal great escape. It turns into a race against time when the Tweedy’s plan to switch from egg production to chicken pies, which leaves little room to the imagination for how it will affect our poultry friends. Voices supplied by Mel Gibson, Julia Sawalha, Miranda Richardson and Timothy Spall.

results.title: Chicken ranch: a legal brothel in Nevada
results.creator_credit: Sandi Sissel, Nicholas Broomfield, Central Independent Television (UK) and Churchill Films
results.brief_description: A documentary film about the best known legalised brothel in America, the Chicken Ranch in Las Vegas. The film observes the day to day lives of the women who work in the brothel. Their average age is 21 and their earnings are split 50/50 with the house.

results.title: Charles Blackman: dreams and shadows
results.creator_credit: Richard Moore, ABC-TV (Australia) and RM Films
results.brief_description: Charles Blackman has been described as the “traditional Aussie battler”. Raised by his mother in a home with no books and little furniture or food, Blackman rose above the insecurity of his life to become one of Australia’s most celebrated artists. A chronological look at Blackman’s life and work and his unique contribution to the development of the Australian identity is provided. Narrated by Kate Fitzpatrick.

results.title: Chick, chick, chick
results.creator_credit: Bob Brown, Mick Brown and Churchill Films
results.brief_description: A cheerful observation of chickens and fowls in a farmyard setting. Includes shots of chickens awakening, stretching, eating, exploring, drinking, encountering other farm animals and a predator, and retreating to mother hen’s wings. Another hen sits on her eggs, and we see a chicken struggle to hatch. Useful for creative expression, language skills, and sensory awareness. Suitable for primary school level.
